reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s opening analogy that narrow targets can still be reached via “honing” (powered flight / evolution). That analogy plays a supporting, motivational role, but the essay’s main work is later: detailed skepticism about WAM-convergence, and conditional optimism via partial AM-convergence plus trade, plus threats/blockers. So centrality is moderate-low: even if the analogy fails, much of the essay’s argument structure remains. The critique has some bite against the specific analogy by noting that evolutionary/competitive selection optimizes for power/fitness proxies rather than moral truth or flourishing; the ‘empire-by-honing’ historical parallel is a plausible failure mode. However, it only partially weakens the attacked portion because (i) the essay does not rely on a claim that selection will optimize for value without further conditions, and (ii) the essay itself later discusses blockers like power concentration, memetics, and evolutionary dynamics that already gesture at this worry. Most claims are broadly plausible (selection gradients differ; state competition often selects for legibility/control), though it overstates how much the essay ‘leans’ on the analogy and doesn’t engage the essay’s own caveats, so correctness isn’t perfect. It is clearly written, focused on one issue, and has little dead weight.
title: Selection pressures favor empire-building traits over moral accuracy
